"There is a kind of Followers likewise, which are dangerous, being      indeed Espials; which enquire the Secrets of the House and beare      Tales of them."--BACON.

paragraph: "Then give me leave that I may turn the key,      That no man enter till my tale be done."

paragraph: Very possibly Chawner's interference in Mr. Bultitude's private affairs has surprised others besides the victim of it; but the fact is that there was a most unfortunate misunderstanding between them from the very first, which prevented the one from seeing, the other from explaining, the real state of the case.
tokens: interference private affair surprise other victim fact be unfortunate misunderstanding very first prevent one see other explain real state case

paragraph: Chawner, of course, no more guessed Paul's true name and nature than anyone else who had come in contact with him in his impenetrable disguise, and his motive for attempting to prevent an interview with the Doctor can only, I fear, be explained by another slight digression.
tokens: course guess true name nature else come contact impenetrable disguise motive attempt prevent interview fear explain slight digression

paragraph: The Doctor, from a deep sense of his responsibility for the morals of those under his care, was perhaps a trifle over-anxious to clear his moral garden of every noxious weed, and too constant in his vigilant efforts to detect the growing shoot of evil from the moment it showed above the surface.
tokens: deep sense responsibility moral care trifle anxious clear moral garden noxious weed constant vigilant effort detect grow shoot evil moment show surface

paragraph: As he could not be everywhere, however, it is evident that many offences, trivial or otherwise, must have remained unsuspected and unpunished, but for a theory which he had originated and took great pains to propagate amongst his pupils.
tokens: evident many offence trivial remain unsuspected unpunished theory originate take great pain propagate pupil

paragraph: The theory was that every right-minded boy ought to feel himself in such a fiduciary position towards his master, that it became a positive duty to acquaint him with any delinquencies he might happen to observe among his fellows; and if, at the same time, he was oppressed by a secret burden on his own conscience, it was understood that he might hope that the joint revelation would go far to mitigate his own punishment.
tokens: theory right minded boy feel fiduciary position master become positive duty acquaint delinquency happen observe fellow same time oppress secret burden own conscience understand hope joint revelation go mitigate own punishment

paragraph: It is doubtful whether this system, though I believe it is found successful in Continental colleges, can be usefully applied to English boys; whether it may not produce a habit of mutual distrust and suspicion, and a tone the reverse of healthy.
tokens: doubtful system believe find successful continental college apply english boy produce habit mutual distrust suspicion tone reverse healthy

paragraph: For myself, I am inclined to think that a schoolmaster will find it better in the long run, for both the character and morals of his school, if he is not too anxious to play the detective, and refrains from encouraging the more weak-minded or cowardly boys to save themselves by turning "schoolmaster's evidence."
tokens: inclined think schoolmaster find good long run character moral school anxious play detective refrain encourage weak minded cowardly boy save turn schoolmaster evidence

paragraph: Dr. Grimstone thought otherwise; but it must be allowed that the system, as in vogue at Crichton House, did not work well.
tokens: think allow system vogue work

paragraph: There were boys, of course, who took a sturdier view of their own rights and duties, and despised the talebearers as they deserved; there were others, also, too timid and too dependent on the good opinion of others to risk the loss of it by becoming informers; but there were always one or two whose consciences were unequal to the burden of their neighbour's sin, and could only be relieved by frank and full confession.
tokens: be boy course take sturdy view own right duty despise talebearer deserve be other timid dependent good opinion other risk loss become informer be conscience unequal burden neighbour sin relieve frank full confession

paragraph: Unhappily they had, as a general rule, contributed largely to the sum of guilt themselves, and did not resort to disclosure until detection seemed reasonably imminent.
tokens: general rule contribute sum guilt resort disclosure detection seem imminent

paragraph: Chawner was the leader of this conscientious band; he revelled in the system. It gave him the means at once of gratifying the almost universal love of power and of indulging a catlike passion for playing with the feelings of others, which, it is to be hoped, is more uncommon.
tokens: leader conscientious band revell system give means gratify universal love power indulg catlike passion play feeling other hope uncommon

paragraph: He knew he was not popular, but he could procure most of the incidents of popularity; he could have his little court of cringing toadies; he could levy his tribute of conciliatory presents, and vent many private spites and hatreds into the bargain--and he generally did.
tokens: know popular procure most incident popularity have little court cring toady levy tribute conciliatory present vent many private spite hatred bargain

paragraph: Having himself a tendency to acts of sly disobedience, he found it a congenial pastime to set the fashion from time to time in some one of the peccadilloes to which boyhood is prone, and to which the Doctor's somewhat restrictive code added a large number, and as soon as he saw a sufficient number of his companions satisfactorily implicated, his opportunity came.

paragraph: He would take the chief culprits aside, and profess, in strict confidence, certain qualms of conscience which he feared could only be appeased by unburdening his guilt-laden soul.
tokens: take chief culprit profess strict confidence certain qualm conscience fear appease unburden guilt laden soul

paragraph: To this none would have had any right to object--had it not necessarily, or at least from Chawner's point of view, involved a full, true, and particular account of the misdoings of each and every one; and consequently, for some time after these professions of misgivings, Chawner would be surrounded by a little crowd of anxiously obsequious friends, all trying hard to overcome his scruples or persuade him at least to omit their names from his revelations.
tokens: have right object have least point view involve full true particular account misdoing one time profession misgiving surround little crowd obsequious friend try overcome scruple persuade least omit name revelation

paragraph: Sometimes he would affect to be convinced by their arguments and send them away reassured; at others his scruples would return in an aggravated form; and so he would keep them on tenterhooks of suspense for days and weeks, until he was tired of the amusement--for this practising on the fears of weaker natures is a horribly keen delight to some--or until some desperate little dog, unable to bear his torture any longer, would threaten to give himself up and make an end of it.
tokens: affect convince argument send reassure other scruple return aggravate form keep tenterhook suspense day week tired amusement practising fear weak nature keen delight desperate little dog unable bear torture threaten give make end

paragraph: Then Chawner, to do him justice, always relieved him from so disagreeable a necessity, and would go softly into the Doctor's study, and, in a subdued and repentant tone, pour out his general confession for the public good.
tokens: do justice relieve disagreeable necessity go study subdued repentant tone pour general confession public good

paragraph: Probably the Doctor did not altogether respect the instruments he saw fit to use in this way; some would have declined to hear the informer out, flogged him well, and forgotten it; but Dr. Grimstone--though he was hardly likely to be impressed by these exhibitions of noble candour, and did not fail to see that the prospect of obtaining better terms for the penitent himself had something to do with them--yet encouraged the system as a matter of policy, went thoroughly into the whole affair, and made it the cause of an explosion which he considered would clear the moral atmosphere for some time to come.

paragraph: The note was too evidently genuine; Dick must have written it (as a matter of fact he had; in a moment of pique, no doubt, at some caprice of his real enslaver Dulcie's--but his fickleness brought fatal results on his poor father's undeserving head)--if this diabolical Chawner carried out his threats he would indeed be "done for"; he did not yet fully understand the other's motive, but he thought that he feared lest Paul, in declaring his own sorrows, might also accuse Tipping and Coker of acts of cruelty and oppression, which Chawner proposed to denounce himself at some more convenient opportunity; he hesitated painfully.

paragraph: At first he was calm and triumphant; his dearest hopes, his long-wished-for opportunity of a fair and unprejudiced hearing, were at last to be fulfilled--Chawner was well out of the way for the best part of two hours--the Doctor was very unlikely to be detained nearly so long over one call; his one anxiety was lest he might not be able, after all, to explain himself in a thoroughly effective manner--he planned out a little scheme for doing this.

paragraph: He must begin gradually of course, so as not to alarm the schoolmaster or raise doubts of his sincerity or, worse still, his sanity. Perhaps a slight glance at instances of extraordinary interventions of the supernatural from the earliest times, tending to show the extreme probability of their survival on rare occasions even to the present day, might be a prudent and cautious introduction to the subject--only he could not think of any, and, after all, it might weary the Doctor.
tokens: begin course alarm schoolmaster raise doubt sincerity bad sanity slight glance instance extraordinary intervention supernatural early time tend show extreme probability survival rare occasion present day prudent cautious introduction subject think weary

paragraph: He would start somewhat in this manner: "You cannot, my dear sir, have failed to observe since our meeting this year, a certain difference in my manner and bearing"--one's projected speeches are somehow generally couched in finer language than, when it comes to the point, the tongue can be prevailed upon to utter. Mr. Bultitude learned this opening sentence by heart, he thought it taking and neat, the sort of thing to fix his hearer's attention from the first.

paragraph: After that he found it difficult to get any further; he knew himself that all he was about to describe was plain, unvarnished fact--but how would it strike a stranger's ear? He found himself seeking ways in which to tone down the glaring improbability of the thing as much as possible, but in vain; "I don't know how I shall ever get it all out," he told himself at last; "if I think about it much longer I shall begin to disbelieve in it myself."

paragraph: And indeed one boy after another came up in the same way as Biddlecomb had done, some cringing more than others, but all vowing that they had never intended to do any harm, and entreating him to change his mind about complaining of his ill-treatment. They brought little offerings to propitiate him and prove the depth of their unaltered regard--pencil-cases and pocket-knives, and so forth, until they drove Paul nearly to desperation. However, he succeeded in dispelling their fears after some hot arguments, and had just sent away the last suppliant, when he saw Jolland too rise and come towards him.

I never thought you would quite come down to this sort of thing!"

paragraph: "Why, going up and letting on against all of us--it's mean, you know. If you have got bashed about pretty well since you came back, it's been all your own fault, and you know it. Last term you got on well enough--this time you began to be queer and nasty the very first day you came. I thought it was one of your larks at first, but I don't know what it is now, and I don't care. I stood up for you as long as I could, till you acted like a funk yesterday. Then I took my share in lamming you, and I'd do it again. But if you are cad enough to pay us all out in this way, I'll have no more to do with you--mind that. That's all I came to say."

paragraph: "Now, then, Chawner," said the Doctor impatiently, "what is it? Have you something on your mind, too?"
tokens: say have mind

paragraph: "Please, sir," said Chawner, "has Bultitude told you anything yet?"
tokens: sir say tell

paragraph: "No, why? Hold your tongue, Bultitude. I shall hear Chawner now--not you!"
tokens: hold tongue hear

paragraph: "Because, sir," explained Chawner, "he knew I had made up my mind to tell you something I thought you ought to know about him, and so he threatened to come first and tell some falsehood (I'm sure I don't know what) about me, sir. I think I ought to be here too."
tokens: sir explain know make mind tell think know threaten come tell falsehood sure know sir think

paragraph: "It's a lie!" shouted Paul, "What a villain that boy is! Don't believe a word he says, Dr. Grimstone; it's all false--all!"
tokens: lie shout villain boy believe word say false

paragraph: "This is very suspicious," said the Doctor; "if your conscience were good, Bultitude, you could have no object in preventing me from hearing Chawner. Chawner, in spite of some obvious defects in his character," he went on, with a gulp (he never could quite overcome a repulsion to the boy), "is, on the whole, a right-minded and, ah, conscientious boy. I hear Chawner first."
tokens: suspicious say conscience good have object prevent hear spite obvious defect character go gulp overcome repulsion boy whole right minded conscientious boy hear

paragraph: "Then, sir, if you please," said Chawner, with an odious side smirk of triumph at Paul, who, quite crushed by the horror of the situation, had collapsed feebly on his chair again, "I thought it was my duty to let you see this. I found it to-day in Bultitude's prayerbook, sir." And he handed Dick's unlucky scrawl to the Doctor, who took it to the lamp and read it hurriedly through.
tokens: sir say odious side smirk triumph crush horror situation collapse chair think duty let see find day prayerbook sir hand unlucky scrawl take lamp read

paragraph: After that there was a terrible moment of dead silence; then the Doctor looked up and said shortly, "You did well to tell me of this, Chawner; you may go now."
tokens: be terrible moment dead silence look say do tell go

paragraph: When they were alone once more he turned upon the speechless Paul with furious scorn and indignation. "Contemptible liar and hypocrite," he thundered, pacing restlessly up and down the room in his excitement, till Paul felt very like Daniel, without his sense of security, "you are unmasked--unmasked, sir! You led me to believe that you were as much shocked and pained at this girl's venturing to write to you as I could be myself. You called it, quite correctly, 'forward and improper'; you pretended you had never given her the least encouragement--had not heard her name even--till to-day. And here is a note, written, as I should imagine, some time since, in which you address her as 'Connie Davenant,' and have the impudence to admire the hat she wore the Sunday before! I shudder, sir, to think of such duplicity, such precocious and shameless depravity. It astounds me. It deprives me of all power to think!"
tokens: alone more turn speechless furious scorn indignation contemptible liar hypocrite thunder pace room excitement feel sense security unmask unmasked sir lead believe shocked pained girl venturing write call forward improper pretend give least encouragement hear name day note write imagine time address have impudence admire hat wear shudder sir think such duplicity such precocious shameless depravity astound deprive power think

paragraph: Paul made some faint and inarticulate remark about being a family man--always most particular, and so forth--luckily it passed unheard.
tokens: make faint inarticulate remark family man particular pass unheard

paragraph: "What shall I do with you?" continued the Doctor; "how shall I punish such monstrous misconduct?"
tokens: do continue punish such monstrous misconduct

paragraph: "Don't ask _me_, sir," said Paul, desperately--"only, for heaven's sake, get it over as soon as possible."
tokens: ask sir say heaven sake get possible

paragraph: "If I linger, sir," retorted the Doctor, "it is because I have grave doubts whether your offence can be expiated by a mere flogging--whether that is not altogether too light a retribution."
tokens: linger sir retort have grave doubt offence expiate mere flog light retribution

paragraph: "He can't want to _torture_ me," thought Paul.
tokens: want _torture think

paragraph: "Yes," said the Doctor again, "the doubt has prevailed. On a mind so hardened the cane would leave no lasting impression. I cannot allow your innocent companions to run the risk of contamination from your society. I must not permit this serpent to glide uncrushed, this cockatrice to practise his epistolary wiles, within my peaceful fold. My mind is made up--at whatever cost to myself--however it may distress and grieve your good father, who is so pathetically anxious for you to do him credit, sir. I must do my duty to the parents of the boys entrusted to my care. I shall not flog you, sir, for I feel it would be useless. I shall expel you."
tokens: say doubt prevail mind harden cane leave lasting impression allow innocent companion run risk contamination society permit serpent glide uncrushed cockatrice practise epistolary wile peaceful fold mind make cost distress grieve good father anxious do credit sir do duty parent boy entrust care flog sir feel useless expel

paragraph: "What!" Paul leaped up incredulous. "Expel me? Do I hear you aright, Dr. Grimstone? Say it again--you will expel me?"
tokens: leap incredulous expel hear say expel

paragraph: "I have said it," the Doctor said sternly; "no expostulations can move me now" (as if Mr. Bultitude was likely to expostulate!) "Mrs. Grimstone will see that your boxes are packed the first thing to-morrow morning, and I shall take you myself to the station and consign you to the home you have covered with blushes and shame, by the 9.15 train, and I shall write a letter to-night explaining the causes for your dismissal."
tokens: say say expostulation move likely expostulate see box pack first thing morning take station consign home cover blush shame train write letter night explain cause dismissal

paragraph: Mr. Bultitude covered his face with his hands, to hide, not his shame and distress, but his indecent rapture. It seemed almost too good to be true! He saw himself about to be provided with every means of reaching home in comfort and safety. He need dread no pursuit now. There was no chance, either, of his being forced to return to the prison-house--the Doctor's letter would convince even Dick of the impossibility of that. And, best of all, this magnificent stroke of good luck had been obtained without the ignominy and pain of a flogging, without even the unpleasant necessity of telling his strange secret.
tokens: cover face hand hide shame distress indecent rapture seem good true see about provide means reach home comfort safety need dread pursuit be chance force return prison house letter convince impossibility good magnificent stroke good luck obtain ignominy pain flog unpleasant necessity tell strange secret

paragraph: But (having gained some experience during his short stay at the school) he had the duplicity to pretend to sob bitterly.
tokens: gain experience short stay school have duplicity pretend sob

paragraph: "But one night more, sir," continued the Doctor, "shall you pass beneath this roof, and that apart from your fellows. You will occupy the spare bedroom until the morning, when you quit the school in disgrace--for ever."
tokens: night more sir continue pass roof fellow occupy spare bedroom morning quit school disgrace

paragraph: I said in another chapter that this Sunday would find Paul, at its close, after a trying course of emotions, in a state of delicious ecstasy of pure relief and happiness--and really that scarcely seems too strong an expression for his feelings.
tokens: say chapter find close try course emotion state delicious ecstasy pure relief happiness seem strong expression feeling

paragraph: When he found himself locked securely into a comfortable, warm bedroom, with curtains and a carpet in it, safe from the persecutions of all those terrible boys, and when he remembered that this was actually the last night of his stay here--that he would certainly see his own home before noon next day, the reaction was so powerful that he could not refrain from skipping and leaping about the room in a kind of hysterical gaiety.
tokens: find lock comfortable warm bedroom curtain carpet safe persecution terrible boy remember last night stay see own home noon next day reaction powerful refrain skip leap room kind hysterical gaiety

paragraph: And as he laid his head down on a yielding lavender-scented pillow, his thoughts went back without a pang to the varied events of the day; they had been painful, very painful, but it was well worth while to have gone through them to appreciate fully the delightful intensity of the contrast. He freely forgave all his tormentors, even Chawner--for had not Chawner procured his release?--and he closed his eyes at last with a smile of Sybaritic satisfaction and gentle longing for the Monday's dawn to break.
tokens: lay head yield lavender scent pillow thought go pang varied event day painful painful worth while go appreciate delightful intensity contrast forgive tormentor procure release close eye last smile sybaritic satisfaction gentle longing dawn break

paragraph: And yet some, after his experiences, would have had their misgivings.
tokens: experience have misgiving
